title: The Power of God's Word and Healing
summary: The sermon focuses on the healing of a crippled man in Acts 14:8-10, emphasizing the integrity and power of God's Word. It highlights Paul's boldness in proclaiming the gospel and the necessity of faith for healing. The message encourages believers to trust in God's power and manifest His works in their lives.
sermon_notes: The story of the crippled man in Acts 14:8-10 illustrates God's power to heal through His Word.
Paul's boldness in preaching the gospel demonstrates the power of God's Word to transform lives.
Faith is essential for receiving healing and manifestation of God's power.
God's integrity and power are constant, while human circumstances and faith are variable.
Healing is a manifestation of the collision between fate and God's Word.
Believers are called to demonstrate God's power and character in their lives.

scripture_references.text: And at Lystra a man sat who had no strength in his feet, who was a cripple from his mother's womb and had never walked. 9 This man was listening to Paul as he spoke. And Paul, looking straight at him and seeing that he had faith to be healed, 10 said with a loud voice, 'Stand up on your feet.' And he sprang up and began walking.
scripture_references.context: Paul preaches in Lystra, and a crippled man is healed through Paul's faith and proclamation.

scripture_references.text: For I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, to the Jew first and also to the Greek.
scripture_references.context: Paul's confidence in the gospel's power is highlighted.

scripture_references.text: as it is written, 'I have made you the father of many nations'—in the presence of the God in whom he believed, who gives life to the dead and calls into existence the things that do not exist.
scripture_references.context: God's power to create and transform is emphasized.

title: Destroyers of Destiny
summary: This sermon highlights eight factors that can destructively influence a Christian's life and destiny, emphasizing the importance of maintaining focus on Godly values and avoiding worldly distractions.
sermon_notes: Worldly desires and excessive pleasure can choke one's destiny.
Worry and anxiety can dominate and hinder a person's life.
Busyness without structure and prioritization can lead to ineffectiveness.
The love of money can become a master and distract from Godly purposes.
Visionless relationships and fear of man can mislead and ensnare.
Sin and disobedience can block spiritual progress and favor.
Baseless arguments and genealogies are unprofitable and destructive.
Unregulated media engagement can corrupt and distract, especially the younger generation.

scripture_references.text: For all that is in the world—the desires of the flesh and the desires of the eyes and pride of life—is not from the Father but is from the world. For the world is passing away along with its desires, but whoever does the will of God abides forever.
scripture_references.context: Warns against the fleeting nature of worldly desires and the importance of abiding in God's will.

scripture_references.text: Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.
scripture_references.context: Teaches believers to replace anxiety with prayer and trust in God's peace.

scripture_references.text: As the king passed by, he cried out to the king. And the king said, 'What is troubling you?' He answered the king, 'This man sent me out, and while I was on the way, your servant Uriah the Hittite died.' So the king said, 'Thus may you do for him: give him a place of honor, and you shall be with me in battle, as was your father before you.''
scripture_references.context: Illustrates the consequences of being overly busy and the importance of prioritization.

scripture_references.text: No one can serve two masters, for either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and money.
scripture_references.context: Warns against the love of money and the necessity of prioritizing God above material wealth.

scripture_references.text: Do not be yoked together with unbelievers. For what do righteousness and wickedness have in common? Or what fellowship can light have with darkness?
scripture_references.context: Advises believers to avoid unproductive and spiritually harmful relationships.

scripture_references.text: But avoid foolish controversies and genealogies and arguments and quarrels about the law, to which they are unprofitable and useless.
scripture_references.context: Warns against engaging in unprofitable debates and arguments that do not contribute to spiritual growth.

title: The Power of Consecration and Priesthood
summary: This sermon emphasizes the importance of consecration and priesthood in the life of a believer, highlighting how deep commitment to God grants spiritual authority and influence.
sermon_notes: Consecration is the foundation of spiritual authority and power.
Intercession is a crucial aspect of carrying the weight of others and influencing spiritual outcomes.
The story of the man dedicating his left ear to God illustrates long-term commitment to divine purposes.
The prosperity of the church depends on the presence of consecrated individuals who intercede and hold spiritual authority.
Without such individuals, the church may decline, and spiritual fire can diminish among believers.

scripture_references.text: I made a covenant with my eyes not to look lustfully at a young woman.
scripture_references.context: Illustrates Job's commitment to consecration and purity.

scripture_references.text: Simon, Simon, Satan has asked to sift all of you as wheat. But I have prayed for you, Simon, that your faith may not fail.
scripture_references.context: Highlights the importance of prayer and intercession in spiritual warfare.

scripture_references.text: To him who loves us and has freed us from our sins by his blood, and has made us to be a kingdom and priests to serve his God and Father—to him be glory and power for ever and ever!
scripture_references.context: Emphasizes believers' role as a kingdom of priests.
